name: HD 215497
scenarioDescription:
The HD 215497 Exoplanetary System

HD 215497 is a star with 0.67 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.85 times its radius. It is located 132.39 light years away from the solar system.

HD 215497 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

HD 215497 b

HD 215497 b was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory using the radial velocity method. Its discovery was announced in 2010-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.05 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 3.93 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, HD 215497.

Its eccentricity, the extent to which the shape of the exoplanet's orbit departs from a perfect circle (Earth's is 0.0167, which is why the shape of Earth's orbit is circular rather than oval in appearance), is 0.16, which means that when HD 215497 b is at is at its closest point to its host star, 0.04 astronomical units separates the two, and when it is at its farthest point, this number is 0.06. In the case of Earth, these numbers are 0.9832899 and 1.0167103 respectively.

The mass of HD 215497 b is 6.36 times the mass of Earth. At 6.36 Earth masses, HD 215497 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

HD 215497 c

HD 215497 c was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory using the radial velocity method. Its discovery was announced in 2010-03. Its semi-major axis is 1.28 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 567.94 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, HD 215497.

Its eccentricity, the extent to which the shape of the exoplanet's orbit departs from a perfect circle (Earth's is 0.0167, which is why the shape of Earth's orbit is circular rather than oval in appearance), is 0.49, which means that when HD 215497 c is at is at its closest point to its host star, 0.65 astronomical units separates the two, and when it is at its farthest point, this number is 1.91. In the case of Earth, these numbers are 0.9832899 and 1.0167103 respectively.

The mass of HD 215497 c is 104.88 times the mass of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HD 215497 c is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system HD 215497, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by La Silla Observatory.
